app.title: SENTINEL
app.tagline: Every child deserves someone who won't stay silent.
app.footer: No data is collected. Everything stays on your device.

nav.identifyDesc: Learn to recognize the signs of abuse
nav.actDesc: Know where and how to report

identify.title: IDENTIFY
identify.subtitle: Select the type of suspected abuse to see common signs.

signs.phy3: Injuries at different stages of healing
signs.phy4: Marks shaped like objects (belt, cord, cigarette)
signs.phy5: Flinches at sudden movements or touch
signs.phy6: Seems constantly on alert or watchful
signs.phy8: Gives inconsistent or unlikely explanations for injuries
signs.emo1: Sudden speech disorders or sleep disturbances
signs.emo2: Physical complaints (headaches, stomachaches) with no medical cause
signs.emo3: Extreme behavior — overly passive or overly aggressive
signs.emo4: Unusually low self-esteem or self-deprecating statements
signs.emo5: Acts inappropriately adult-like or regresses to younger behavior
signs.sex3: STDs or pregnancy in a child under 14
signs.sex5: Fear of a specific person or place
signs.neg1: Visible malnutrition or significant weight loss
signs.neg5: Complains of constant hunger or hoards food
signs.neg7: Takes on adult responsibilities (caring for siblings, cooking)

emergency.title: Immediate concern
emergency.description: The signs you selected suggest a situation that may require urgent attention. A child's safety could be at risk right now.

high.title: High level of concern
high.description: Multiple serious signs were identified. Reporting to the appropriate authority is strongly recommended.

medium.title: Moderate level of concern
medium.description: Several signs were identified. Recording your observations and continuing to monitor the situation is recommended.
medium.extra: Continue observing and document any changes over time.

low.title: Low level of concern
low.description: A few signs were noted. While they may not confirm abuse on their own, it is good practice to document and remain attentive.
low.extra: Stay attentive and note if additional signs appear over time.

identify.emptyState: Choose a category above to see the signs associated with each type of abuse. If you're unsure, select "I'm not sure" to see all signs at once.
identify.callout: A single sign does not confirm abuse. The combination of signs, repetition over time, and context are what should raise concern. It is not your role to investigate — it is your role to report.

document.title: DOCUMENT

cases.empty: You haven't started tracking any situations yet. If you've noticed something concerning about a child, start a case to document your observations over time.

act.title: ACT
act.subtitle: What to do when you suspect a child is being abused.

do.title: What to do
do.step1: Stay calm. Don't show shock, anger, or despair.
do.step2: If the child told you something: believe them. Tell them it's not their fault.
do.step4: Report to the appropriate authority (see channels below).
do.step5: Remember: you don't need proof. A well-founded suspicion is enough.

dont.title: What not to do
dont.step1: Do NOT confront the suspected abuser.
dont.step2: Do NOT interrogate the child with leading questions.
dont.step3: Do NOT investigate on your own — leave that to professionals.
dont.step4: Do NOT wait for absolute certainty — delay can cost the child's safety.
dont.step5: Do NOT discuss with many people — protect the child's identity and dignity.
dont.step6: Do NOT react with anger or disbelief if the child tells you something.

notes.canada: Child abuse reports in Canada are handled by provincial/territorial child protection agencies. Contact your local Children's Aid Society or equivalent service.
notes.usa: Childhelp provides guidance and referrals. To file a report, contact your local Child Protective Services (CPS) or law enforcement directly.

script.title: Suggested reporting script
script.intro: When calling, be prepared to provide:
script.item1: Brief description of the situation observed.
script.item3: Description of the child (approximate age, gender).
script.item4: Information about the suspected abuser (relationship to child).

faq.title: Frequently asked questions
faq.q1: Do I need to identify myself?
faq.a1: In most countries, no. Reports can be anonymous.
faq.a2: No. Suspicion is enough. It's the authorities' job to investigate.
faq.a3: Good-faith reports are protected by law. It is always better to report than to stay silent.
faq.a4: The receiving agency evaluates the report and determines next steps. Response times vary by country and severity of the situation. In urgent cases, authorities may act immediately.

sources.title: SOURCES
sources.subtitle: All content in this app is based exclusively on official protocols. No guidance is based on opinion.
sources.commitment: Before publication, all content will be reviewed by social work and child psychology professionals. This project has direct responsibility for children's safety and accepts no margin for error.
